titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Donald Pippin Collection MUS.0003
titlestmt.author: Patrick Vallez-Kelly

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2017-08-30 16:07:37 -0700.

physdesc.extent: 72 PDF documents; 276 TIF facsimiles; 2 MS Word 97-2003 documents; 20 video (mp4) files.

did.physloc: Stanford Music Library, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94305-3076

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with repository. Publication and reproduction rights reside with the creators or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Head Librarian of the Stanford Music Library.

acqinfo.head: Source
acqinfo.p: The Donald Pippin Collection was donated to the Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound by Donald Pippin in 2013.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Born in Zebulon, North Carolina, and educated at Harvard University, Donald Pippin began his musical career as an accompanist at George Balanchine’s School of American Ballet in New York City. In 1952, Pippin moved to San Francisco, and has been an integral part of that city's artistic life since then. He did not immediately find a showcase for his talents following his move to the Bay Area. He therefore started his own recital series at North Beach's hungry i, and later at Opus One. From here, Pippin branched into small chamber ensemble presentations, working with Bay Area musicians, to present works across multiple genres, from medieval and baroque, to contemporary music, often by California composers. During the 1960s, these performances developed into a series entitled Sunday Evening Concerts, held at the Old Spaghetti Factory in San Francisco, that would become the city's primary home for chamber music.

Unexpectedly, these predominantly instrumental chamber music performances metamorphosed into vocal recitals, culminating in a number of one-act operas which became very popular with audiences at the Old Spaghetti Factory. Pippin felt strongly about making opera accessible to as wide an audience as possible and therefore started to create original English language transcriptions of each work. These translations have since become the core of Pippin's musical life, encompassing a wide range of genres, nationalities, and musical styles.

In 1975, Pippin took on his boldest move to date by presenting Verdi's little performed opera, King for a Day. From its success sprung "Pocket Opera," an organization dedicated to presenting professional performances of operatic works in intimate, intelligible productions at affordable prices. In 1977, prompted by the success of these early performances, members of the audience met and incorporated Pocket Opera as a non-profit organization.

By 1979, a subscription series was established, and the size of the audience forced the company out of the North Beach cabaret halls it had occupied and into the theaters of San Francisco. In the years since, Pocket Opera has performed an annual spring season with a growing repertory of operas. The many achievements of the company include rediscoveries, premieres, and revitalization of works long neglected--some of them previously unperformed in the United States. The Pocket Opera Press published Pippin's translations which are now performed by companies throughout the country: from San Diego to Philadelphia and from Houston to Ann Arbor. Pocket Opera's performances have been broadcast in the San Francisco Bay Area and elsewhere, some live broadcasts reaching as many as 10,000 listeners. Pippin has identified many notable singers and has been instrumental in nurturing their careers. Some singers who started with Pocket Opera have gone on to sing in major opera companies in the United States and abroad.

More information on Pippin and Pocket Opera can be found in "A Pocketful of Wry: An Impresario's Life in San Francisco and the History of the Pocket Opera, 1950s-2001" available at http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=kt238nb0dm&brand=calisphere&doc.view=entire_text

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Donald Pippin Collection consists primarily of Pippin's numerous English translations of operatic libretto. Additional materials include facsimiles of over 300 print media reviews of Pocket Opera productions; copies of two anthologies published by Pippin, "A pocketful of lyrics" and " As the lights go up…: tales from the opera"; a speech on Offenbach given by Pippin in San Francisco in 1996; a tribute ode by Anne Dudley on the occasion of Pippin's 60th birthday; and finally an interview with Pippin published in Journal Français d'Amérique in 1996.

odd.head: SDR
odd.p: This is a self deposited collection in the SDR.

odd.head: Date information
odd.p: All dates obtained from Donald Pippin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two files. One contains just the translated libretto. The other contains both the translated libretto and translated narration text.

As the lights go up ... : tales from the opera

dao.xlink:title: As the lights go up ... : tales from the opera

daodesc.p: As the lights go up ... : tales from the opera: 2005

scopecontent.head: Summary
scopecontent.p: This file contains many of Pippin's narrative introductions to acts of the many operas that the Pocket Opera Company has performed.

did.physdesc: The PDF document includes the title page, dedication, table of contents, and preface sections of this anthology, which are missing from the MS Word document. These additional sections have been scanned from a hard copy of the anthology. This has resulted in incorrect page numbering at the start of the document. The preface is numbered as pages 1-4. Page numbering then starts again at page 1 for the first chapter, Marriage of Figaro.

scopecontent.head: Contents summary
scopecontent.p: Alternate title : A world of lyrics. This file contains Pippin's English translations for arias from multiple operas along with texts for introductory and linking narrations and, in some cases, graphics of music notation for the first lines of the arias. At the end of the document is list of operas that Pippin has translated to English.

Arias included are from the following operas: Marriage of Figaro/Mozart -- Don Giovanni/Mozart -- Cosi fan tutte (The way of women)/Mozart -- Abduction from the seraglio=Yanked from the harem/Mozart -- Magic flute/Mozart -- Barber of Seville/Rossini -- Cenerentola=Cinderella/Rossini -- Italian girl in Algeria/Rossini -- Count Ory/Rossini -- Elixir of love/Donizetti -- Don Pasquale/Donizetti -- Lucia di Lammermoor/Donizetti -- Lucrezia Borgia/Donizetti -- Macbeth/Verdi -- Rigoletto/Verdi -- Traviata/Verdi -- Falstaff/Verdi -- Halka/Moniuszko -- Haunted manor/Moniuszko -- Orpheus in the underworld/Offenbach -- Belle Helene/Offenbach -- Vie Parisienne/Offenbach -- Bandits/Offenbach -- Bridge of sighs : Carnival in Venice/Offenbach -- Perichole/Offenbach -- Princess of Trebizonde/Offenbach -- Bluebeard/Offenbach -- Tales of Hoffman/Offenbach -- Bartered bride/Smetana -- Two widows/Smetana -- Carmen/Bizet -- Eugene Onegin/Tchaikovsky -- Queen of Spades/Tchaikovsky -- Manon/Massenet -- Boheme/Puccini -- Madame Butterfly/Puccini -- Tosca/Puccini -- Manon Lescaut/Puccini -- Rondine=The swallow/Puccini -- Merry widow/Lehar -- Cunning little vixen/Janacek.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 20 digital files of operatic performances: 1. Merry wives of Windsor / Otto Nicolai -- 2. Pocket Opera gala (02-23-2014) -- 3. The magic flute / Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart -- 4. Eugene Onegin / Peter Ilich Tchaikovsky -- 5. Agrippina / George Frideric Handel -- 6. The pearl fishers / Georges Bizet -- 7. The merry widow / Franz Lehár -- 8. Don Pasquale / Gaetano Donizetti -- 9. Alcina / George Frideric Handel -- 10. I pagliacci / Ruggiero Leoncavallo -- 11. My fair Galatea / Franz von Suppé -- 12. Cosi fan tutte / Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart -- 13. Pocket Opera gala (01-24-2016) -- 14. Martha / Friedrich von Flotow -- 15. King for a day / Giuseppe Verdi -- 16. Giulio Cesare / George Frideric Handel -- 17. I pagliacci / Ruggiero Leoncavallo -- 18. My fair Galatea / Franz von Suppé -- 19. Rigoletto / Giuseppe Verdi -- 20. La vie parisienne / Jacques Offenbach.
